reasoning: The critique targets a moderately central assumption: that agents/coalitions will have time and incentive to engage in moral reflection, bargaining, and ‘aiming’ rather than being pre-empted by a fastest-takeoff recursive/self-improving process. If true, that would undercut large parts of the essay’s sections 2–4 (convergence/trade deliberation) by making outcomes driven by first-mover capture/lock-in. However, the essay already flags related ‘blockers’ (early lock-in, lack of deliberation, concentration of power), so the attack is not fully novel nor fully position-collapsing. Argumentative strength is limited because it mostly asserts a speed/compute-penalty dominance claim without support (no model of takeoff regimes, whether “aiming” necessarily slows capability acquisition, whether safety/alignment is instrumentally required for sustained expansion, etc.). Several claims are overstated (‘necessarily’ incurs a decisive penalty; ‘regardless of its aim’), but the general concern about first-mover advantage in fast takeoff scenarios is plausible. The critique is very clear, tightly focused, and contains little dead weight.
title: Speed advantage of non-aiming agents undermines the premise of reflective course correction
